description_html:
This gallery contains images of America's Founding Fathers.

The American Presidents 1700s-1800s gallery contains images of other Founding Fathers.
story_html:
This gallery is a work in progress.

You can find spiritual portraits of George Washington, John Adams, and Thomas Jefferson in the American Presidents 1700s-1800s gallery on this site.

To keep up to date, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Alexander Hamilton
image_list.subtitle_html: Founding Father and First Secretary of the Treasury of the USA — Sep. 11, 1789 to Jan. 31, 1795
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Alexander Hamilton's spiritual portrait shows he was outgoing, pragmatic, and extremely rational and decisive.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Alexander Hamilton's dominant personality trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait when he used logic to write pamphlets explaining his position on controversial issues, such as the assumption of state debts by the federal government for the Revolutionary War.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Alexander Hamilton's auxiliary personality trait, his realistic outlook.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait in his ongoing insistence that America needed a strong military to protect its borders and presence on the seas.
image_list.story_intro_html: Alexander Hamilton was born on January 11 of either 1755 or 1757, in Charlestown, the capital of the island of Nevis in the Caribbean Sea. Although no one is sure which year he was born, it is certain he was ....

image_list.title: Benjamin Franklin
image_list.subtitle_html: Founding Father and Sixth President of Pennsylvania
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Benjamin Franklin's spiritual portrait shows he was outgoing, open-minded, and logical.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Benjamin Franklin's dominant personality trait, his openness to new ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait by imagining and creating inventions, such as lightening rods, bifocal glasses, and the Franklin stove.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Benjamin Franklin's auxiliary personality trait, his preference for objectivity over subjectivity.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait in the way he regarded all religions to be equal and did not consider any single one of them to be any better than the others.
image_list.disclosure_html: This page contains affiliate marketing links. Clicking on one of these links then making a purchase helps us continue to keep SeeOurMinds.com online.
image_list.story_html_work_in_progress_finish_this_:
Work on Benjamin Franklin's story is in progress.

To learn when there is new content on SeeOurMinds.com, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

Completing this story is a top priority, so check back in a week or two!

Following is a sneak peek at Franklin's story:

Born in Boston on January 17, 1706, Benjamin Franklin was by far the oldest of the main Founding Fathers of the United States. Ben was 26 years old when George Washington, the second-oldest, was born on February 22, 1732, and either 48 or 50 when Alexander Hamilton, the youngest, was born on January 11, 1755 or 1757.

America's First Celebrity

Famous for his experiments with electricity.

Extremely popular in France.

Perceptive

Comfortable with ideas, but not a theorist.

Did not pursue scientific endeavors unless there was a pragmatic use for the technology.

Has not the famous political Fable of the Snake, with two Heads and one Body, some useful Instruction contained in it? She was going to a Brook to drink, and in her Way was to pass throâ€™ a Hedge, a Twig of which opposed her direct Course; one Head chose to go on the right side of the Twig, the other on the left, so that time was spent in the Contest, and, before the Decision was completed, the poor Snake died with thirst.

Out-going

Formed Junto groups

Blue: Idealism

Green: Logic

This spiritual portrait is based on the biography Benjamin Franklin: An American Life, by Walter Isaacson. There is also a nice American Experience video available.

image_list.title: Patrick Henry
image_list.subtitle_html: Founding Father, and First and Sixth Governor of Virginia
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Patrick Henry's spiritual portrait shows he was outgoing, warmly decisive, and pragmatic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Patrick Henry's dominant personality trait, his amiability and passion.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait in his passionate speeches, such as his famous and dramatic plea to 'Give me liberty, or give me death!'
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Patrick Henry's auxiliary personality trait, his realism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait when, faced with the realization that slavery was immoral, he could also see abolition would be too drastic a change to the nascent economy in such a young nation.  Accordingly, he did what he could by supporting legislation in the Virginia General Assembly to allow manumission of existing slaves and to limit, and eventually halt, the importation of new slaves.
